explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid (melting point <= 140degC) substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (Si, Ge, As, Sb, Bi, etc.).

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The substance does not contain oxygen, fluorine or chlorine.

organic_peroxides.rationale: The substance does not contain a peroxide-related atomic group (O-O).

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 values of 522mg/kg for males and 701mg/kg (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), 2003) plus 900mg/kg for females (SIDS, 2000), the substance was classified into Category 4.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Since no mortality occurred in rabbits administered at 5010 and 7940mg/kg (SIDS, 2000), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Old documents indicate that the substance is not irritating to slightly irritating to humans without providing definite conclusions (SIDS (2000)). Furthermore, in rabbit studies, the substance was determined to be slightly irritating, since 1 out of 3 treated rabbits showed signs of irritation 12 hours after the treatment, but they disappeared within 24 hours (IUCLID (2000)). Based on these test results in humans and rabbits , the substance is indicated to be "no irritating" in the SIDS. Thus, the substance was classified into "Not classified".

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In rabbit tests, the following was documented: mild erythema was seen in the conjunctivas 24 hours after application, but they disappeared in 48 hours (SIDS, 2000); moderate irritation was observed 24 hours after application (SIDS, 2000); the results ranged from not irritating to slight irritating (IUCLID, 2000); and mechanical irritation was seen in 2 out of 3 rabbits treated (IUCLID, 2000). Based on these descriptions, the substance was classified into Category 2B.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: In skin sensitization tests using guinea pigs, reactions were observed in 70% of the animals (SIDS, 2000), thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

carcinogenicity.rationale: No test results using germ cells are not available. In vivo genotoxicity tests (SCE) yielded negative results (BUA 207, 1996, IUCLID 2000) while in vitro mutagenicity tests (chromosomal aberration tests) (SIDS 2000) and in vitro genotoxicity assays (SCE) (SIDS 2000) both gave positive results. Based on these results, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Since no data on humans and animals are available, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: No sufficient data available for classification.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (liver, kidney, blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In oral route tests using rats, toxic symptoms were observed in the liver (centrilobular hepatocytes hypertrophy, increased mitotic figures of hepatocytes, and extramedullary hematopoiesis of the liver), kidney (regeneration of urinary tubules and infiltration of lymphocytes in kidney medulla), and spleen (excessive extramedullary hematopoiesis) at 455mg/kg bw or above (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), 2003). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 2 (liver, kidney, blood system).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, blood system)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: In 28-day repeated oral administration tests using rats, toxic symptoms were observed in the blood (decreased erythrocytes, hemoglobins, and hematocrit values), liver (swelling, hypertrophy of acidophilic hepatocytes, fatty degeneration of the intermediate zone of the lobule, and necrosis of single cells), and spleen (swelling, hemosiderin deposition, and reinforced increase of extramedullary hematopoiesis) at 100mg/kg bw (90-day conversion: 31mg/kg bw) or above (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), 2003). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 2 (liver, blood system).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour EC50 = 0.34mg/L for fish (rainbow trout) (SIDS, 2000), the substance was classified into Category 1.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its acute toxicity is Category 1 and it is not rapidly degradable (non-biodegradable, BOD degradability: 2.2% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1994)), the substance was classified into Category 1.
